subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] King Kong updates
msgSnippet: It s telling the OS to make code points between U+E660 and U+E67F, α la . If the font you re using doesn t have glyphs
messageBody:
It's telling the OS to make code points between U+E660 and U+E67F, à la <http://www.frogorbits.com/qs/csur.html>. If the font you're using doesn't have glyphs for those code points, though, you'll see question marks or dots or boxes as a "glyph not found" marker.

You'll need to switch to fonts that have glyphs for these code points; they tend to have "Uni" or "Unicode" in the name (to distinguish them from fonts that squat on code points used for Latin letters). Some (all?) of these fonts are available in the Files section of this group.

If you have a favorite font that doesn't seem to have a Unicode version anywhere, try and contact the original author to see if they can make a proper Unicode version that uses the newfangled Private Use Area code points. If that fails, send the .ttf/.otf to me — I'll be able to assign the glyphs to the proper code points, as well as give the font a good home.

If my explanation wasn't clear, please do ask for clarification on the list — this sort of thing is mildly complicated if you've never had to deal with this sort of thing before.

— Nathan




On Aug 25, 2013, at 5:46 PM, raghaillaigh <vin.reilly@...> wrote:

>
>
> Nathan, I've got the updated keyboard installed on Win 7 64, but it isn't producing characters, just dots or rectangles. Is the keyboard expecting to find a particular QS font?
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:
>>
>> I've just updated King Kong with a bunch of changes. I've moved the en and em dashes from % and T to T and G; the middle dot (·) on G got moved to H, and % is now used for _.
>>
>> The Windows version has also been updated to match, and the installer now ships with *all* the files it needs (as opposed to just the setup.exe shell).
>>
>> Grab it from <https://github.com/adiabatic/king-kong>.
>>
